Dialogue:
ES: Hello!  
CD: Hello!  
ES: What did you eat for lunch?  
CD: Pasta.  
ES: Did you make it yourself?  
CD: Yes, with tomato sauce.  
ES: Did you make the sauce too?  
CD: No, I bought it and added anchovies.  
ES: Do you often have anchovies at home?  
CD: I recently got some. Do you like them?  
ES: Not sure, are they made from fish?  
CD: Yes, sardines.  
ES: Can you find them in the pasta section?  
CD: Yes.  
ES: What do they taste like?  
CD: Fishy.  
ES: I'll look for them next time.  
CD: What did you have for lunch?  
ES: Curry.  
CD: At home?  
ES: Yes, frozen rice and instant curry.  
CD: Muji curry is tasty.  
ES: Which one is your favorite?  
CD: Butter chicken curry.  
ES: Do you enjoy spicy food?  
CD: Yes.  
ES: I prefer green curry.  
CD: Is it very spicy?  
ES: Yes.  
CD: That might be too spicy for me.

ES: Hello.
CD: Hello.
ES: Do you usually listen to music?
CD: Yes, I do! I'm listening now.
ES: What kind of music do you like?
CD: I'm listening to "Just Look Up" by Ariana Grande.
ES: Sounds interesting! I'll check it out later.
CD: Have you heard of the movie "Look Up"?
ES: No, is it recent?
CD: Yes, it's on Netflix, and that's where the song is from.
ES: I'll listen to the song on YouTube later.
CD: The movie is also recommended. Do you listen to Western music?
ES: Yes, I do. I liked Fifth Harmony during their peak.
CD: Is that when there were five members?
ES: Yes, they lost momentum after one member left.
CD: Camila, right? I liked her too.
ES: Yes, exactly! Do you follow a lot of Western music?
CD: Mostly. So, I don't know many songs at karaoke.
ES: Who else do you like besides Ariana?
CD: I enjoy classics like Taylor and Justin.
ES: I used to listen to Justin's older songs a lot.
CD: I feel we might be around the same age.
ES: I think so too! I loved "Beauty and the Beat" with Nicki Minaj.
CD: That's a great song! 
ES: It's still exciting even though it's old.
CD: Yes, Justin looked really young in that video.
ES: I enjoyed our conversation!
CD: Me too! Thanks for chatting!

ES: Hello.
AR: Hello, how can I assist you today?
ES: I'm feeling a bit nervous.
AR: Do you often feel nervous around new people?
ES: Yes, I do.
AR: Understood. I also get nervous during significant events.
ES: Are you referring to events like presentations?
AR: Yes. When I was younger, I used to write the character for 'people' (人) three times on my palm to calm down.
ES: I remember that trick! It's quite nostalgic.
AR: Many people used to do it.
ES: I don't recall how I learned it, but I did it too. There's also the idea of imagining the audience as potatoes.
AR: Yes, that's another common method.
ES: Do kids today still do things like writing 人人人?
AR: My children are still young, so they don't understand it yet.
ES: Your children are young! I hope you teach them when they grow older.
AR: We can play nostalgic games like Alpus Ichiman Shaku and Glico Pineapple Chocolate together.
ES: Such games are timeless. Do you play outside?
AR: Yes, my children love being outside. They have a lot of energy.
ES: A friend of mine mentioned how energetic her son is.
AR: There's a noticeable difference in how boys and girls play. Girls are often calmer.
ES: Indeed, boys and girls play differently.
AR: I'd like to try matching outfits with a girl at least once. Boys can be very affectionate.
ES: Is your child also affectionate?
AR: Yes, but I feel girls are more straightforward.
ES: I see. Being affectionate is always nice.
AR: It brings out a nurturing side. I'm sure men find their daughters adorable too.
ES: It's common for mothers and sons, fathers and daughters to bond well. Kids are wonderful.
AR: Their purity is valuable. I hope they stay that way.
ES: The purity of children is indeed precious.
AR: Yes, very much so. Take care and see you again!

ES: Hello.  
EV: Hello.  
ES: What did you eat for lunch today?  
EV: Cold udon.  
ES: Did you freeze it?  
EV: No, I cooled it after boiling.  
ES: Perfect for summer. How does it taste?  
EV: Good with mentsuyu.  
ES: That sounds nice. I've been trying different udon flavors.  
EV: Many variations available.  
ES: Yes, it keeps it interesting.  
EV: Toppings and seasonings help.  
ES: What do you prefer as toppings?  
EV: Egg and green onion.  
ES: Simple is good.  
EV: Yes, sometimes soy sauce.  
ES: Soy sauce is tasty. I've been adding rice cakes.  
EV: Like udon with mochi?  
ES: Yes, sometimes with miso.  
EV: Understood.  
ES: It's also good with gochujang or doubanjiang.  
EV: Noted.  
ES: Do you lose your appetite in the summer?  
EV: Yes, I get tired.  
ES: Same here. I'm looking for food ideas.  
EV: Spicy food helps.  
ES: In summer, spicy foods are appealing. Can you handle spicy?  
EV: Medium spicy is okay.  
ES: I tend to get an upset stomach.  
EV: Noted.

ES: Hello!  
EV: Hello, nice to meet you.  
ES: What do you usually do during this time?  
EV: "Playing games or reading manga, right? On holidays."  
ES: Sounds like a great way to unwind. What kind of games do you play?  
EV: "I often play hunting games and RPGs. The hardware is PS4."  
ES: Interesting! Do you play any games on your smartphone?  
EV: "I play a little. I play baseball and Dragon Ball games."  
ES: Baseball games on smartphones? I'd like to try one!  
EV: I also started it on a recommendation from a friend. It might be a good way to kill time.  
ES: What's the name of the baseball game?  
EV: "It's called Prospi. If you don't like rigid games, PowerPro is better."  
ES: Is it a game where you can use real athletes as characters?  
EV: Yes, that's right. They often feature it in commercials.  
ES: Sounds intriguing. Do you like baseball in general?  
EV: Yes, I watch it from time to time.  
ES: I've also gotten into it recently. Do you have a favorite team?  
EV: "I don't have any favorite. I like watching close games on my computer."  
ES: Close games are thrilling, aren't they? I want to watch a Nippon-Ham Fighters game.  
EV: My home is in Hokkaido, so it's a bit far. If it's a visitor, somehow.  
ES: It would be great if there was a game nearby.  
EV: Is there a stadium nearby where I can watch a game?  
ES: Since I'm in Tokyo, I can go to the Dome. I'd love to watch a game there!  
EV: I see. It's nice that it's not affected by the climate.  
ES: Have you watched a live game before?  
EV: About 10 years ago, but yes, it exists.  
ES: Is it really different from watching on TV?  
EV: Sure. The translated sentence is: "That's right. The cheering squad is there, so the excitement is conveyed."  
ES: The sound must be amazing in person.  
EV: Yes, I don't really understand much about types of pitches.

ES: Nice to meet you, please take care of me.
EV: Nice to meet you. How can I assist you today?

ES: Have you been on any trips recently?
EV: I won't be traveling due to the current situation.

ES: It's quite difficult to go, isn't it?
EV: Yes, I was planning to visit my parents this month, but that plan was canceled.

ES: Is it because COVID-19 is spreading again?
EV: Yes. My mother has contracted COVID.

ES: Eh! Is your mother okay?
EV: Yes, her treatment has already finished.

ES: I see. There are people around me who have lingering aftereffects.
EV: I understand. My mother works at a hospital, so there are risks.

ES: In this day and age, I admire that you are working at a hospital.
EV: Yes, that's true. There was a period when it calmed down, but the situation is escalating again.

ES: Didn't your family get disappointed when you canceled your trip home?
EV: No, it couldn't be helped since we can't enter the house.

ES: I see, it would be nice if you could visit your hometown again.
EV: Yes, I hope to return in the winter.

ES: Do you remember what the infection situation was like last winter?
EV: It was quite prevalent. I went back but stayed in a hotel to monitor my health.

ES: There are a lot of things to be considerate about, aren't there?
EV: Yes, it had calmed down around spring, but now it's increasing again.

ES: The situation remains one where we cannot let our guard down recently.
EV: Yes. Traveling isn't bad, but there's a higher risk if one gets too excited at the destination.

ES: After all, when you go back to your hometown or travel, you want to go out, don't you?
EV: That's right. We want to enjoy our trip since we are spending money.

ES: I understand the feeling of wanting to have fun if you're going to do it anyway.
EV: We have to endure it for a while. Let's take care of our health.

ES: Let's take care of our health!
EV: Yes, thank you very much.

ES: Hello!  
DN: Hello.  
ES: Have you decided on tonight's dinner?  
DN: No. Have you?  
ES: Not yet. I bought pork yesterday.  
DN: Pork belly?  
ES: Thinly sliced pork.  
DN: Menu planning hard?  
ES: Yes. How do you decide?  
DN: Evening sales items.  
ES: Cheaper in the evening?  
DN: Yes, especially fish and sashimi.  
ES: Cook it immediately?  
DN: Mostly arrange.  
ES: Like grilling meat?  
DN: Yes, with sauce and vegetables.  
ES: Sauce in seasoning section?  
DN: Retort pouches in curry and Chinese section.  
ES: I'll check it out.  
DN: Use pasta sauce with meat and vegetables.  
ES: Which flavor?  
DN: Tomato sauce with chicken or minced meat and vegetables.  
ES: Minced meat cooks quickly!  
DN: Yes. Dilute clam vongole sauce for soup.  
ES: Sounds good!  
DN: Add white fish, clams, and mushrooms.  
ES: Use the white fish as is?  
DN: Yes, pre-processed.  
ES: Helpful, thanks!  
DN: Pasta sauce is versatile!

ES: Hello, nice to meet you.  
DN: Hello. Nice to meet you.  
ES: Have you been on a trip recently?  
DN: No, I went outside the prefecture, but I didn't go on a trip.  
ES: I understand, it's quite a difficult time to go out.  
DN: Correct. I sometimes take the express bus to visit my son in Kansai on weekends.  
ES: Oh, you're in Kansai! Are you from Kanto?  
DN: No, I travel from Aichi to Osaka and Kobe.  
ES: I see. I'm in Tokyo now, but I'd like to visit Aichi and Osaka too.  
DN: My other son is in Kanagawa, and I sometimes take the bus there as well.  
ES: You seem experienced with bus travel. Do you like it?  
DN: The Shinkansen is expensive, but the bus is affordable.  
ES: Yes, it doesn't cost even half as much as the Shinkansen.  
DN: There are high-speed buses with capsule seats between Aichi, Osaka, and Tokyo.  
ES: Capsule seats! Are they private?  
DN: Yes, they are designed for legroom and privacy.  
ES: That sounds intriguing and private.  
DN: Yes, I prefer the three-row seats on the Aichi-Tokyo route, but the capsule is the best.  
ES: Are all three rows capsules?  
DN: Yes, only 17 seats, all capsules.  
ES: Few seats! Is there a restroom on the bus?  
DN: This company's buses do not have restrooms.  
ES: That's concerning. Are there bathroom breaks?  
DN: Yes, three breaks: before midnight, around 5 AM, and another in between.  
ES: In that case, it's alright! It seems you can eat without worries.  
DN: Yes, the rest areas are well-equipped, and I've played a public piano at Hamamatsu SA.  
ES: Oh, like the town piano program on NHK?  
DN: Yes, it's popular lately.  
ES: Have you appeared on it?  
DN: No, I just play and then leave.
